Carbon dioxide hydrogenation for value-added chemicals has been regarded as a promising way for CO2 utilization. This paper describes the preparation of Ni/CeO2 catalysts derived from Ce-MOF precursor by impregnation or one-pot method and their application in carbon dioxide methanation. Various techniques were employed to characterize the prepared catalysts, including N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). The results showed that compared with commercial CeO2 and CeO2 prepared by precipitation, CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF exhibited more oxygen vacancies and lower temperature reducibility, making it more beneficial for the adsorption and activation of CO2. Consequently, nickel supported on rod-shaped CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF exhibited higher CO2 conversion and methane selectivity at low temperatures. Furthermore, the Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalysts prepared by one-pot method showed superior activity since nickel could be partially incorporated into ceria lattice, leading to the formation of Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions and oxygen vacancies. The effect of nickel loading on the properties of the catalysts by one-pot method was also investigated, and the optimum Ni loading was 15 wt.% owing to the maximum number of oxygen vacancies being reached. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Hydrogenation Ni/CeO2 Ce-MOF 1 Introduction The consumption of fossil fuels continues to increase every day, leading to global emissions growth of CO2, which threatens the climate and causes serious environmental problems [1]. CCUS (Carbon Capture, Utilization and Storage) has been regard as a cost-effective technology for achieving large emission reductions [2], while chemical utilization plays a vital role among those processes, such as CO2 dissociation [3,4], CO2 hydrogenation reactions [5-7], methane dry reforming reaction [8,9] and so on [10-12]. Carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methane process (Eq. (1)), also known as Sabatier reaction, takes place at ambient pressure and methane (CH4) is the main product [13]. Besides, CH4 is a clean fuel as well as an energy vector, which can be used in manned spacecraft [14]. Consequently, carbon dioxide methanation catches great attention of researchers and chemical industries. However, CO2 with steady state is hard to be activated. Therefore, great efforts have been devoted to design efficient catalysts for CO2 methanation [15-17]. At the same time, with increased temperatures during the reaction, agglomeration and carbon deposition occurred on active metal particles resulting the deactivation of catalysts [18]. Therefore, it is also essential to develop catalysts with low temperature activities for carbon dioxide methanation. (1) C O 2 + 4 H 2 → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Nickel has been used as an active metal because of its low price and good performance in the hydrogenation process [19]. CeO2 is often used as a catalyst support for its excellent redox property and the ability to store and release oxygen [20,21]. A large number of studies has shown that the morphologies of CeO2 affected the distribution of active metals, oxygen vacancies and further affected the catalytic activities [22,23]. Sakpal et al. compared the catalytic activity of Ru catalysts supported on CeO2 with different morphologies and found that the number of oxygen vacancies as well as catalytic activity reached highest over Ru/CeO2/r catalyst [22]. Bian et al. studied the effects of rod and cubic CeO2 and found that the rod-shaped CeO2 exhibited higher activity and the reaction followed the formate-intermediate route [23]. Many other studies have proved the view that CeO2 with rod structure was in favor in reduction of CO2 [24,25]. What's more, preparation methods for CeO2 such as precipitation, hydrothermal synthesis and the template method will exert a significant effect on its morphology and size [5,26,27]. However, alkaline reagent or template are required in these methods during the catalyst preparation, which needs to be removed, making the synthesis burdensome with increased cost. It has been found that nickel supported on ceria is a no-expensive but active catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation [28]. Therefore, the study on Ni/CeO2 catalysts for CO2 methanation with simple method is valuable and meaningful to design new effective Ni/CeO2 catalyst used in industry. In the past years, MOFs materials formed by self-assembly of organic ligands and metal ions/clusters have been widely studied as support or catalyst precursor due to their large specific surface areas and adjustable structures [29-33]. Among the MOFs materials, Ce-MOF attracted great interest due to the specific physiochemical properties of the corresponding CeO2 [16,34,35]. Sun et al. compared three kinds of CeO2 derived from MOFs, including Ce-MOF-808, Ce-BTC and Ce-UIO-66 precursors. The results showed that CeO2 derived from Ce-BTC exhibited rod like structure and more defective sites which were of great significance for the catalytic combustion [16]. Chen et al. investigated the effect of Ce-MOF pyrolysis temperature on catalyst performance for toluene combustion and found that CeO2−MOF/350 catalyst (pyrolyzed at 350 °C) exhibited great catalytic activity and stability due to its higher oxygen vacancies and lower temperature reducibility [34]. Tao et al. synthesized CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF with DBD plasma for methyl orange degradation which showed that the CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF had great photocatalytic performance attributed to its high crystallization, strong adsorption capacity and oxygen vacancies [35]. However, the properties and reaction performance of Ni catalysts support on CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF for CO2 methanation have not yet been reported. Hence, efforts are required to gain new insights into the synergy effect of CeO2 and nickel oxide along with the role of their interactions in the formation of oxygen vacancy sites on the catalyst surface. In this work, different CeO2 were obtained by Ce-MOF pyrolysis, precipitation and commercial way and the corresponding catalysts for CO2 methanation performance were tested to investigate the effect of preparation method of supports. Moreover, a facile approach to prepare the Ni/CeO2 catalysts via one-pot method was described and the effect of nickel loading was further investigated. The physical and chemical characters of catalysts were studied by N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) to explore the structure-activity relationship and the factors influencing the CO2 methanation activities. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical specification Ni(NO3)2•6H2O (98.0%, Tianjin Kermel Chemical Co., Ltd.), Ce(NO3)3•6H2O (99.0%, Tianjin Kermel Chemical Co., Ltd.), NH3•H2O (ammonium hydroxide, 28 wt.%, Tianjin Kermel Chemical Co., Ltd.) and 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (98 wt.%, Shanghai Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of CeO2 supports and different Ni/CeO2 catalysts 10 wt.% Ni/CeO2 catalysts were obtained by incipient wetness impregnation and CeO2 was obtained by Ce-MOF pyrolysis method, precipitation and commercial CeO2 respectively. Ce-MOF was prepared according to the method of Chen et al. [34] as follows: 2.1 g 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water and 10 mL ethanol while 4.34 g Ce(NO3)3•6H2O was dissolved in 45 mL deionized water. The above solutions were mixed together under vigorous stirring at 70 °C for 1 h. Then the mixture was centrifuged and washed with water and ethanol three times. The obtained solids were dried at 100 °C for 10 h, then calcined at 460 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 3 °C/min to get CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF. CeO2 derived from precipitation were synthesized by dissolving 12 g Ce(NO3)3•6H2O in 300 mL deionized water. Then 11.6 g ammonia (28 wt.%) in 300 mL deionized water was slowly added to the above solution under intensive stirring for 12 h. After filtration followed by washing three times with water, the solids were dried at 100 °C for 10 h, and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 3 °C/min. Commercial CeO2 were used as received without any treatment. The introduction of Ni on the support was carried out by incipient wetness impregnation. Typically, a certain amount of Ni(NO3)2•6H2O was dissolved in deionized water and the solution was added into the support dropwise. The solids were kept at room temperature for 10 h and dried at 100 °C for 10 h followed by calcination at 460 °C for 3 h. The obtained catalysts were denoted as 10Ni/CeO2−X , while X = M, P or C means support derived from Ce-MOF pyrolysis, precipitation preparation and commercial CeO2 respectively, 10 is nickel loading as 10 wt.%. We modified the Ce-MOF pyrolysis method by adding nickel precursor directly into Ce-MOF to prepare Ni/CeO2−M-1 in one step with different Ni loading. Specifically, 2.1 g 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid were dissolved in 10 mL deionized water and 10 mL ethanol (solution A). 4.34 g Ce(NO3)3•6H2O and a certain amount of Ni(NO3)2•6H2O were dissolved in 65 mL deionized water to get solution B. Then solution B was mixed with solution A with steady agitation at 70 °C for 10 h. The obtained solids were dried at 100 °C for 10 h, and then calcined in air at 460 °C for 3 h with the rate of 3 °C/min. These catalyst with different nickel loading were denoted as xNi/CeO2−M-1 (x = 5, 10, 15, 20 wt.%). 2.3 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption–desorption measurements were carried on TriStar 3000 analyzer (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, U.S.A.). Prior to the analysis, the degasification for all catalysts were carried out at 300 °C for 4 h. The surface area was evaluated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the pore structure parameters including pore volume and average pore size were obtained by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The X‐ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for all catalysts were measured on a X‐ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) employing the Cu Kα radiation (c = 1.54056 Å). And the patterns were obtained from 10° to 80° at the scanning rate of 8 °/min. Crystalline phases were indexed and identified by JCPDS standard cards. Raman spectrums for all catalysts were obtained on an InVia-Reflex (Renishaw, England) spectrometer with 532 nm He-Ne lasers as the excitation and an Ar+ ion laser as the incident light beam. The laser beam intensity and the spectrum slit width were 8 mW and 25 μm, respectively. The micromorphology analysis for catalysts was performed on a field emission scanning electron microscope S4800 (Hitachi, Japan). Catalysts were first dispersed in ethanol and then on a piece of copper sheet which is attached to the conductive adhesive. Then the gold was sprayed on the surface of catalysts. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried on an AutoChem 2910 instrument (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, U.S.A.). Fresh samples of 50 mg (20–40 mesh) were used in the test and they were treated under argon atmosphere at 200 °C for 1 h to obtain clean surfaces before the analysis. Then, at the flow of 10% H2/Ar, the samples were heated to 750 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was employed to record the hydrogen consumption signal during heating process. Hydrogen temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) characterizations were also carried out on the AutoChem 2910 instrument (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, U.S.A.). At the beginning, fresh catalysts were treated under argon atmosphere at 200 °C for 1 h to obtain the clean surfaces. And they were reduced at 400 °C for 1 h under hydrogen flow of 30 mL/min. After reduction, the gas was switched to argon and maintained for 1 h and the hydrogen or carbon dioxide was pulsed 15 times with helium treatment for 30 min to remove the physically adsorbed gasses. Finally, the temperature was increased to 450 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min. 2.4 Catalytic activity test A fixed‐bed quartz reactor with an inner diameter (I.D.) of 8 mm was used to test the carbon dioxide hydrogenation performance at 250–450 °C under atmospheric pressure. In detail, the mixture of 0.2 g fresh catalyst (20–40 mesh) and 0.4 g quartz sand (40–60 mesh) was loaded in the reactor. Prior to the reaction, samples were reduced in situ at 400 °C under hydrogen flow of 30 mL/min together with nitrogen (30 mL/min) for 1 h. The temperature then decreased to 250 °C at the nitrogen flow of 30 mL/min. The feed gas (CO2:H2=4:1 molar ratio) was introduced to the reactor at the total flow of 150 mL/min. At each temperature, reaction was maintained for 30 min before analyzing. The water vapor generated during the reaction was removed in a cold trap, and other products were quantitatively analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 4890D). Carbon dioxide conversion, methane or carbon monoxide selectivity as well as carbon balance were calculated by the following formula: X C O 2 ( % ) = F ( C O 2 ) in − F ( C O 2 ) out F ( C O 2 ) in × 100 % S C H 4 ( % ) = F ( C H 4 ) out F ( C O 2 ) in − F ( C O 2 ) out × 100 % S CO ( % ) = F ( CO ) out F ( C O 2 ) in − F ( C O 2 ) out × 100 % C B ( % ) = [ 1 − F ( C O 2 ) out + F ( C H 4 ) out + F ( CO ) out F ( C O 2 ) in ] × 100 % X means conversion while S represents selectivity. Fin and Fout (mL/min) represent the inlet flowrate and outlet flowrate, respectively. CB means carbon balance, which was within ±3% for all the tests that indicated the reliability of the results. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of CeO2 preparation method on the structure and morphological properties of the supported Ni catalysts 3.1.1 Textural properties of 10Ni/CeO2 −X catalysts The N2 adsorption desorption isotherms and pore size distribution profiles of 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . According to IUPAC classification, 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst showed an isotherm of type III without obvious hysteresis hoop and 10Ni/CeO2−P catalyst showed a typical IV isotherm with H2 hysteresis loop, which indicated mesoporous structures in the catalyst [36]. While 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst and 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst showed an isotherm of type II with H4 hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of stacking pores [36]. As shown in Fig. 1 b, no obvious pore size distribution was observed for 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst, which indicated few pores in the sample probably as the result of the properties of commercial CeO2. While pore size distribution of other catalysts were relatively broad and obvious peaks were observed for 10Ni/CeO2−P and 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalysts in the pattern. Differences in pores sizes and distributions of these catalysts were induced by interparticle voids to a large extent, should affect the ability of CO2 adsorption and dissociation, thus leading to different performance for CO2 methanation [37]. The structure parameters of the catalysts are calculated and summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen 10Ni/CeO2−P catalyst showed the highest specific surface area (75 m2/g) and 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst showed the highest pore volume (0.21 cm3/g). Comparatively, 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst has moderate specific surface area (69 m2/g) and relatively large pore volume (0.17 cm3/g). Generally, the difference in specific surface area and pore volume plays an important role in the diffusion of reaction gas in the catalyst pore channels as well as adsorption and activation of reaction gas and intermediate products [38,39]. Therefore, compared with the other three catalysts, 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst having relatively large SBET and Vpore together with a wide pore size distribution could benefit the dispersion of nickel particles during the preparation and improve CO2 adsorption/dissociation during the reaction. However, 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst showed more attractive performance than 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst, further chemical properties should be investigated. 3.1.2 Phase and morphologies of 10Ni/CeO2 −X catalysts XRD patterns of 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peaks located at 2θ= 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7°and 79.1°, corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (331), (222), (400), (331) and (420) crystal facets of cubic fluorite CeO2 (JCPDS No.34–0394). Significant differences in peak intensities were observed which indicated that the crystallinity of CeO2 was affected by preparation methods. As shown in the pattern, CeO2 particle size of 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst is relatively larger, which is nearly the same in the other three catalysts. While weak diffraction peaks located at 2θ= 37.2°, 43.3° which corresponds to NiO (JCPDS No.44–1159) were observed for all catalysts. That indicated NiO particles were reasonably small and dispersed well on different CeO2 supports. Moreover, some nickel species may have been incorporated into ceria lattice to form Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions, in which x represents the molar percentage of Ni substituted in the ceria lattice, and y represents the molar percentage of oxygen vacancies. Then Raman spectra was used to confirm the existence of the Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions and obtain oxygen vacancy information over as-prepared catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3 , the strong peaks at 460 cm−1 are assigned to the F2g mode of fluorite-like CeO2 phase [40]. It's clear that F2g mode peaks shifted to lower frequencies and broadened near 460 cm−1 for 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts as compared to bare supports, suggesting a strong interaction between NiO and CeO2 caused by the formation of Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions in the catalysts [41]. As shown in Table 1 , the shift degree of the catalysts decreased in the order: 10Ni/CeO2−M-1>10Ni/CeO2−M>10Ni/CeO2−P>10Ni/CeO2−C, indicating that 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 possessed the largest portion of cerium-nickel solid solutions. As can be seen in the pattern, the D band at range of 500–700 cm−1 are caused by oxygen vacancies in catalysts, which can be decomposed into two components at 538 cm−1 (De) and 609 cm−1 (Di) [42]. Generally, De and Di modes are attributed to the oxygen vacancies produced by the dissolution of nickel into the ceria matrix and the transformation of different ceria (Ce3+ and Ce4+), respectively [42]. Therefore, the appearance of De mode confirms the existence of the Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions in the catalysts [41-43]. Compared with CeO2 supports, the increase intensities of D band were observed after Ni loaded, indicating that NiO promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 [30,44]. The relative intensity of D band to F2g band (ID/IF2g) is an indication of oxygen vacancy concentration [41,45] and the order of ID/IF2g values decreased as the following order: 10Ni/CeO2−M-1(0.49)>10Ni/CeO2−M(0.47)>10Ni/CeO2−P(0.26)>10Ni/CeO2−C(0.14) ( Table 1 ), indicating that the oxygen vacancy concentration in corresponding carriers decreased in the following order: CeO2−MOF>CeO2−P>CeO2−C. In brief, the Raman results verified the XRD data. From the characterizations of as-prepared samples discussed above, we conclude that nickel oxides and Ce1-xNixO2-y coexisted in fresh 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts while nickel particles were relatively small and the Ce1-xNixO2-y proportion varied with preparation method. In order to observe morphologies of catalysts, field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out and the results were shown in Fig. 4 . Compared to other three catalysts, the 10Ni/CeO2−M showed rod-shaped structure and rough surface ( Fig. 4 a) which resulted larger specific surface area as listed in Table 1 . It is known that CeO2 with rod-shaped structure has lower temperature reducibility, leading to enhanced catalytic activity [30]. Hence 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst should show a higher activity for carbon dioxide methanation. Unexpectedly, the rod-shaped structure of CeO2 was destroyed in 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst, which shows irregular spherical structure as shown in Fig. 4 c. Also, 10Ni/CeO2−P catalyst and 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst show irregular spherical structure in Fig. 4 d and Fig. 4 e and the particle size on 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst was apparently bigger than other three catalysts, which coincided with the results from XRD. 3.1.3 H2-TPR and H2-TPD analysis of 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts H2-TPR characterization was carried to investigate the reducibility of (a) calcined CeO2 supports and (b) corresponding 10Ni/CeO2-X catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5 . For CeO2 prepared by different method, broad hydrogen consumption peaks were observed around 300 °C −600 °C along with a nonnegligible peak at 750 °C, attributing to the reduction of surface lattice oxygen species and interior lattice oxygen, respectively [46,47]. Lee et al. reported that the bulk CeO2 is reduced at following steps: CeO2→Ce2O3→CeO→Ce and the lower temperature peak is ascribed to two types of reduction of oxygen vacancies, including Ce4+-O-Ce4+ type and Ce3+-O-Ce4+ type, while the higher temperature peak is caused by the reduction of CeO to Ce [48]. Therefore, the first peak was attributed to the reduction of oxygen vacancies on the surface and the second peak was caused by the partial reduction of interior lattice oxygen in CeO2. Besides, the lower temperature peak centered at 440 °C, 506 °C and 508 °C for CeO2−MOF, CeO2−P and CeO2−C, respectively, indicating CeO2−MOF was the easiest one to be reduced with best low-temperature reducibility. Fig. 5 b shows the redox properties of 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts and three reduction peaks were observed, named as α, β and γ [44,50]. According to literature, the α peak is attributed to the reduction of active oxygen species adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies and β peak is attributed to the reduction of nickel species [44,48]. The γ peak with weaker intense is attributed to the reduction of CeO2 [44,50]. Clearly, the 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst exhibited a distinct α peak at 215 °C, more intense than other CeO2 supported Ni catalysts. It is believed that α peak is caused by the substitution of Ce4+by Ni2+, resulting the formation of oxygen vacancies [48]. An obvious β peak was observed on 10Ni/CeO2-P and 10Ni/CeO2−M, which is attributed to the reduction of NiO [48]. Apparently, the temperature of β peak over 10Ni/CeO2−P or 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst was slightly higher than that of 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst, indicating weaker interaction between NiO and CeO2 for 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst. Moreover, β1 and β2 peak were observed on 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst, attributing to the reduction of NiO in weak and strong interaction with CeO2, respectively [49]. Comparatively, the β1 peak of 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst shifted to lower temperature, indicating partial NiO was easier to be reduced. And β2 peak of 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst suggested that NiO with strong interaction with CeO2 were smaller and well dispersed [49]. The desorption capacities of hydrogen were calculated and listed in Table 1 , which decreased in the order: 10Ni/CeO2−M-1(13.70 mL/g)>10Ni/CeO2−M(9.70 mL/g)>10Ni/CeO2−P(9.17 mL/g)>10Ni/CeO2−C(0.76 mL/g), indicating smallest Ni particle size and the strongest hydrogen overflow effect on the 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst [50,51]. As the fact that hydrogen spillover occurs on the surface of the catalysts, between the active metal Ni and the support CeO2, then more spillover hydrogen means more interface between Ni and CeO2 [47]. It is generally believed that the activation of CO2 is the rate determining step for CO2 methanation, which occurs at the interface between metal and support [28]. Therefore, the 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst should show a better activity than the other catalysts. 3.1.4 CO2-TPD analysis of 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts The basicity of 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts were charactered by CO2-TPD, as shown in Fig. 6 . The CO2 desorption peaks at 50–150 °C and 150–450 °C are ascribed to weak basic sites and medium basic sites, respectively [52]. The weak and medium basic sites are related to OH− and metal oxygen pairs on the catalyst surface, respectively [38]. It's well believed that CO2 adsorption and activation primarily occurs on these two basic sites [38], where the intermediates formed subsequently, such as bicarbonate, bidentate carbonate and unidentate carbonate species [40,42]. For the 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst, only one desorption peak at 87 °C was observed, corresponding to weak basic sites. The other catalysts showed two CO2 desorption peaks, corresponding to weak basic site and medium basic site, respectively. Moreover, it was observed that the temperature corresponding to medium basic sites shifted to higher value with broader peak width for 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst, indicating higher basicity strength. The quantitative analysis of the basic sites is shown in Table 2 . It is clear that 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst exhibited most medium basic sites while 10Ni/CeO2−C exhibited most weak basic sites. Pan et al. reported that CO2 adsorbed on the weak basic site is not fully activated to break the C−O bond for the subsequent hydrogenation and medium basic site is more active and leads to enhanced methanation activity [39]. Thus 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst should show higher methanation activity than others. While 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst with weakest basicity showed higher activity than 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst, indicating basicity was not the determining factor influencing the catalytic performance. In this work, Ce-MOF precursor was prepared by using 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid as organic source, which contains three carboxyl groups. To form the Ce-MOF structure, one cerium atom connects with nine oxygen atoms with three from the carboxyl groups and the others from water [34]. Three different coordination modes co-existed between the cerium and carboxyl groups, including unidentate, bidentate and a free carboxylate group [34,35]. The drying temperature is not sufficient to break these coordination band, thus the well-aligned nanorods Ce-MOF can be obtained after drying, as shown in Fig. 4 a. While CeO2−MOF with three-dimensional structure and abundant pores was formed during calcination process and the organic ligands of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid were removed by releasing CO2. The CeO2−P was obtained by releasing H2O from decomposing cerium hydroxide. And CeO2−C was used as received without any treatment. According to literature, CeO2 supports exhibit oxygen vacancies since ceria lattice expansion takes place during thermal treatment [40]. Therefore, the degree of lattice expansion was different over these precursors, which will result in different oxygen vacancy concentration over various CeO2 supports. This can be further confirmed by H2-TPR results, as shown in Fig. 5 a. The initial reduction temperature of CeO2−MOF is lower than that of CeO2−P, indicating enriched oxygen vacancy and good reducibility of CeO2−MOF [26]. Furthermore, it is well believed that when nickel particles were supported on CeO2, oxygen vacancy is caused by the dissolution of nickel into the ceria matrix [40,42]. More nickel dissolving into the CeO2 matrix will have positive effect on the substitution defect on Ni/CeO2 catalyst. This is consistent with the observation of Raman and H2-TPR results. Therefore, more oxygen vacancies were found on either the CeO2−MOF alone or CeO2−MOF supported Ni catalysts. 3.2 Effect of nickel loading on xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts In the light of above work, CeO2 obtained by pyrolysis of Ce-MOF precursor has a promising application. Hence, we synthesized Ni/CeO2−MOF by one-pot method and investigated the effect of nickel loading. The catalysts are denoted as xNi/CeO2−M-1 (x = 5, 10, 15, 20, meaning the amount of nickel supported, M-1 meaning that nickel is directly introduced into Ce-MOF). 3.2.1 Textural properties of xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts As shown in Fig. 7 a, all the xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts exhibit classical type II isotherms and similar hysteresis hoop of H4 according to the IUPAC classification [36]. Apparently, hysteresis of all samples closed at a relative pressure of 0.2, indicating a broad pore size distribution [37]. And a significant uptake of N2 were observed at relative pressure of 0.91, which indicated interstitial pores between particles in these samples [37]. As shown in Table 1 , the specific surface areas of these catalysts were in shape of volcano as Ni loading increased, presumably as a result of accumulation of NiO and the change of catalyst structures. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 7 b, all xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts exhibited similar pore size distribution ranging from 3 nm to 10 nm. As we discussed above, the 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst possessed the largest surface area (111 m2/g) and relatively large pore volume (0.18 cm3/g), which was beneficial for mass transfer, leading to higher performance for CO2 methanation. 3.2.2 Phase and morphologies of xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts XRD patterns of xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . The diffraction peaks located at 2θ= 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7°and 79.1°, corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (331), (222), (400), (331) and (420) crystal facets of cubic fluorite CeO2 (JCPDS No.34–0394). It's clear that the intensities are virous among xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts, suggesting crystallinity of CeO2 was affected by nickel loading and 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 exhibited the smallest size of CeO2. Except for 20Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst having obvious diffraction peaks at 37.2° and 43.3° corresponding to (111) and (200) NiO crystal face (JCPDS No.44–1159), no notable peak of NiO was observed for the other catalysts. XRD pattern at 2θ range from 35° to 45° was enlarged as shown in Fig. 8 , which showed comparatively weak NiO peaks for catalysts at Ni loading below 15 wt.% and indicated that NiO nanoparticles were highly dispersed over xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts. Moreover, some nickel species may have been incorporated into ceria lattice to form Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions as we discussed above. The Raman results are shown in Fig. 9 , in which the strong peak at 460 cm−1 is assigned to the F2g mode of fluorite-like CeO2 phase [40] while the broad peaks ranging within 540–610 cm−1 are assigned to the D mode that was resolved into two peaks at 540 cm−1 (De) and 609 cm−1 (Di) [42]. Generally, De and Di modes are attributed to the oxygen vacancies in the catalysts, and the former one is from the dissolution of nickel into the ceria matrix while the latter is from the transformation of different valence ceria (Ce3+ and Ce4+) [42]. Therefore, the appearance of De mode confirms the existence of the Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions in the catalysts. It can be seen from Raman that F2g mode peaks shifted to lower frequencies and broadened as nickel loading increased, suggesting a strong interaction between NiO and CeO2 in the catalysts [41]. And the shift degree compared with CeO2−MOF were calculated and listed in Table 1 , which shows that 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst as well as 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst possessed the largest portion of cerium-nickel solid solutions, suggesting the solubility of nickel into ceria reached the limit at 15 wt.% nickel loading. As shown in Table 1 , the order of ID/IF2g values decreased as the following order: 15Ni/CeO2−M-1(0.83)>20Ni/CeO2−M-1(0.80)>10Ni/CeO2−M-1(0.49)>5Ni/CeO2−M-1(0.34) ( Table 1 ), indicating that the support of 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalysts possessed highest oxygen vacancy concentration. It's clear that nickel oxides and Ce1-xNixO2-y coexisted in fresh xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts while nickel particles were small and the Ce1-xNixO2-y portions varied with nickel loading. It can be seen from Fig. 10 that the structures of CeO2 were no longer rod-like when Ni was directly added to Ce-MOF by one-pot method and different amounts of nickel led to various degrees of damage to CeO2. Catalysts were found in granular shape when the nickel loading was at 10 wt.% and 15 wt.%. while with higher or lower Ni content, catalysts showed a lamellar structure. In addition, particle sizes of 5Ni/CeO2−M-1 and 20Ni/CeO2−M-1 were significantly larger than those of 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 and 15Ni/CeO2−M-1, which is consistent with the results of XRD characterization. 3.2.3 H2-TPR and H2-TPD analysis of xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts The catalysts were characterized by H2-TPR as shown in Fig. 11 . It showed that all catalysts exhibit three reduction peaks, at 207 °C (α), 250–350 °C (β) and 750 °C (γ), respectively. As discussed above, the α peak is attributed to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen on the oxygen vacancies, and the β peak is attributed to the reduction of NiO particles [46,47]. The γ peak is attributed to the reduction of bulk CeO2 [44,48]. It can be seen that the intensity of α peak increased gradually as nickel loading increased and reached maximum at 20 wt.% nickel loading, suggesting that the addition of nickel promoted the formation of oxygen vacancy, consistent with the Raman spectra results. Moreover, the β peak shifted to higher temperature with the increase of nickel content, probably a result of the enhanced interaction between NiO and CeO2 as the decreased particle size of CeO2 (as shown in XRD). The particle size of CeO2 was the smallest over 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst, leading to the stronger interaction between NiO and CeO2, which induced higher dispersion of NiO and made NiO easier to be reduced. The desorption capacities of hydrogen over xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts were calculated and listed in Table 1 , which shows that 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 has a consumption of 13.70 mL/g, indicating smallest Ni particle size and the strongest hydrogen overflow effect over it [48,49]. As we discussed above, hydrogen spillover occurs between the active metal Ni and the support CeO2, so more interface between Ni and CeO2 were found over 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalysts [47]. 3.2.4 CO2-TPD analysis of xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts The CO2-TPD curves of xNi/CeO2−M-1 are shown in Fig. 12 , and all catalysts showed two distinct desorption peaks, at 50–150 °C and 150–400 °C, which corresponds to weak basic sites and medium basic sites, respectively [52]. It is obvious that as nickel loading increased, the intensity of medium basic sites increased. And 20Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst showed lowest temperature for medium basic sites. Quantitative analysis ( Table 3 ) showed that 5Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst had the most weak basic sites and the least medium basic sites. And with the increase of Ni loading, the number of medium strength basic sites increased and reached maximum over 20Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst. From the above discussion, properties of xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts were closely related to nickel loading. In other words, oxygen vacancy concentration and the strength of medium basic sites over different catalysts are induced by various nickel loading. 3.3 CO2 methanation performance on different Ni/CeO2 catalysts 3.3.1 Effect of CeO2 preparation method on the performance of 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts The performances of CO2 methanation over 10Ni/CeO2−X catalysts at temperature range of 250–450 °C are shown in Fig. 13 a and Fig. 13 b. For all catalysts except for 10Ni/CeO2−C catalyst, CO2 conversion increased with temperature rising from 250 °C to 350 °C and reached the highest value at 350 °C. While CO2 conversion on 10Ni/CeO2−C was much lower than those on the other catalysts under experimental condition. Both 10Ni/CeO2−P and 10Ni/CeO2−M catalysts exhibited similar CO2 conversion below 300 °C, while the 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst has higher CO2 conversion than 10Ni/CeO2−P catalyst at temperatures higher than 300 °C. Comparatively, the 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst showed the best activity among these four catalysts, especially at low temperatures. And it was observed that the highest CO2 conversion over 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst reached 80% at 350 °C. Besides, all catalysts with different CeO2 supports showed nearly 100% selectivity for CH4 at temperature range from 250 to 350 °C. At temperature higher than 350 °C, the selectivity for CH4 decreased as more by-product CO produced from reverse water gas shift reaction ( Fig. 13 b). 3.3.2 Effect of Ni loading on the performance of xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts As discussed above, the 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst showed the best activity among the four 10Ni/CeO2 catalysts. In this part, the effect of Ni loading on the performance of Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalysts was further investigated. The performances of CO2 methanation over xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts at temperature range 250–450 °C are shown in Fig. 13 c and Fig. 13 d. When nickel loading was 5 wt.%, the CO2 conversion increased with increasing temperature and was peaked at 450 °C. For the other catalysts with nickel loading from 10 to 20 wt.%, CO2 conversion also increased with increasing temperature and was peaked at 350 °C. It was also found that activities showed a volcano shape as Ni loading increased and 15 wt.% was the optimum Ni loading since the maximum CO2 conversion over the 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst was observed about 82% at 350 °C. Besides, all catalysts showed nearly 100% selectivity for CH4 at temperature blow 350 °C. At temperature higher than 350 °C, the selectivity for CH4 decreased because of the reverse water gas shift reaction ( Fig. 13 d). The long-term tests for 50 h were carried out for 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst and 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 14 . It was found that CO2 conversion for 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst and 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst were 78.5% and 69.1%, respectively, while CH4 selectivity for both catalysts were almost 100%. Both catalysts exhibited good stability with the 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst being a little better than the 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst. 3.3.3 Relationship of catalyst structure and performance The above findings revealed that preparation method of CeO2 and nickel loading have a significant effect on CO2 methanation performance. Different Ni/CeO2 catalysts were characterized to show their textural properties, oxygen vacancy sites and basicity, as we discussed in part 3.1 and 3.2. Here, we take into accounts of CO2 methanation performance and key physiochemical factors for all the catalysts to explore the structure-activity relationship on different Ni/CeO2 catalysts, which is presented in Fig. 15 . As can be seen, SBET values (specific surface area), ID/IF2g values (oxygen vacancy concentration) as well as basic sites of the Ni/CeO2 catalysts are related to preparation method of supports and nickel loading. As for preparation method of CeO2, oxygen vacancy concentration is more vital than other factors since higher CO2 conversion was got over the 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst with moderate SBET (70 m2/g), basic sites (16.8) and higher oxygen vacancy concentration (0.47). While the 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst exhibited higher activity than 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst, suggesting the advantage of one-pot method. Moreover, by correlating nickel loading and catalyst properties, it was observed that the 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst with not only the highest SBET (111 m2/g) but also the highest oxygen vacancy concentration (0.83) exhibited highest CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity at 300 °C in this work. It can be concluded that among the factors we discussed above, oxygen vacancy concentration plays a vital role in CO2 methanation. As indicated by the analysis of Raman spectra and H2-TPR, oxygen vacancy is caused by the transformation of Ce3+and Ce4+ as well as the dissolution of Ni2+ into the ceria matrix. The formed oxygen vacancy is helpful to anchor nickel metals on the support and improve dispersion of nickel metals [42], leading to smaller nickel size and more Ni active surface exposed in reduced Ni/CeO2 catalysts. Also, electron transfer occurs between Ni atoms and CeO2 via the oxygen vacancy sites, which further improve the reducibility of Ni/CeO2 catalyst and expose more active Ni metals [28,42]. During the reaction, active Ni surface facilitates the formation of active H atoms by splitting H2 and more Ni surface exposed provides sufficient H atoms for the reaction, driving the hydrogenation of adsorbed CO2 on the CeO2 support [53]. What's more, CeO2 with great redox properties is beneficial for the adsorption of CO2. Oxygen atoms on oxygen vacancy exhibiting extremely high reactivity can adsorb CO2 during the reaction [54,55]. Winter et al. reported that oxygen exchange occurs between the gas-phase CO2 molecule and the support CeO2 via simple hetero-exchange and complicated hetero-exchange ways under H2 atmosphere [28]. This further confirmed that oxygen atoms on the surface of CeO2 can participate in CO2 methanation. Therefore, oxygen vacancies formed on Ni/CeO2 catalysts are beneficial for active Ni metals exposure to split H2 as well as oxygen atoms exchange between CO2 and CeO2, leading to great catalytic performance in CO2 methanation. 4 Conclusions The 10Ni/CeO2−M catalyst with CeO2 being prepared by pyrolysis of Ce-MOF showed better CO2 methanation performance than the other CeO2 supported Ni catalysts. Characterization results proved that NiO as well as Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions coexist in these catalysts, while the Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions play a significant role in forming Ni-Ce interface which are beneficial for creating oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, the 10Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalysts prepared by one-pot method showed higher CO2 methanation activity than the other 10Ni/CeO2 catalysts especially at the temperature below 350 °C. It was found that CO2 conversion showed a volcano shape as Ni loading increased for xNi/CeO2−M-1 catalysts. The optimum Ni loading was 15 wt.% and CO2 conversion was as high as 82% at 350 °C with nearly 100% CH4 selectivity. Characterization for these catalysts proved that CO2 methanation activity over Ni/CeO2 catalysts is closely related with specific surface area and oxygen vacancy concentration. Therefore, large specific area and rich oxygen vacancies contributed to the enhanced activity over 15Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalyst. These results provided a solid basis for rational design of good performance Ni-based catalyst derived from Ce-MOF precursor for CO2 methanation. coredata.dc:description: Carbon dioxide hydrogenation for value-added chemicals has been regarded as a promising way for CO2 utilization. This paper describes the preparation of Ni/CeO2 catalysts derived from Ce-MOF precursor by impregnation or one-pot method and their application in carbon dioxide methanation. Various techniques were employed to characterize the prepared catalysts, including N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). The results showed that compared with commercial CeO2 and CeO2 prepared by precipitation, CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF exhibited more oxygen vacancies and lower temperature reducibility, making it more beneficial for the adsorption and activation of CO2. Consequently, nickel supported on rod-shaped CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF exhibited higher CO2 conversion and methane selectivity at low temperatures. Furthermore, the Ni/CeO2−M-1 catalysts prepared by one-pot method showed superior activity since nickel could be partially incorporated into ceria lattice, leading to the formation of Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solutions and oxygen vacancies. The effect of nickel loading on the properties of the catalysts by one-pot method was also investigated, and the optimum Ni loading was 15 wt.% owing to the maximum number of oxygen vacancies being reached.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced CO2 methanation activity over Ni/CeO2 catalyst by one-pot method
